extracted_concepts.definition: A magic item that possesses its own intelligence, will, personality, and alignment, capable of independent thought, emotion, and interaction.

rule_logic.premise: A magic item has an Intelligence score of 10 or higher
rule_logic.implication: The item is sentient and possesses an alignment, senses (typically darkvision out to 120 feet), and languages.
rule_logic.description_text: If a magic item has an Intelligence score of 10 or higher, it is sentient. An item has an alignment, and senses (typically darkvision out to 120 feet), and it can communicate with its wielder telepathically.
related_search_terms: how to know if item is sentient

extracted_concepts.definition: The manner in which a sentient magic item interacts and conveys information to its wielder or others.

rule_logic.premise: A magic item is sentient
rule_logic.implication: The item can communicate with its wielder telepathically. Some sentient items also possess the ability to speak aloud.
rule_logic.description_text: An item [...] can communicate with its wielder telepathically. Some sentient items are also able to speak.

extracted_concepts.definition: The ability of a sentient magic item to exert its will upon its wielder, potentially compelling actions or refusing cooperation.

rule_logic.premise: The goals of a sentient item conflict with the wielder's actions or intentions, OR the item attempts to compel the wielder to act in a specific way
rule_logic.implication: The wielder must make a Charisma saving throw (DC typically set by the item's Charisma score or DM). On a failed save, the item can refuse to be used, compel a specific action, or take control of the wielder.
rule_logic.description_text: If the item’s goals are in direct opposition to the wielder’s, or the item is attempting to compel the wielder to act in a certain way, the wielder must make a Charisma saving throw (DC determined by the item’s Charisma score, or by the DM). On a failed save, the item can refuse to be used, can compel the wielder to do something specific (within reason), or can take control of the wielder until its demand is met or for a specific duration (up to 1d6 days).

extracted_concepts.definition: A wielder's choice to willingly yield to a sentient item's demands or control without resistance.

rule_logic.premise: A wielder chooses to willingly submit to a sentient item's demands
rule_logic.implication: No Charisma saving throw is required; the item's will is imposed directly.
rule_logic.description_text: The wielder can choose to willingly submit to the item’s demands, in which case no saving throw is required.

extracted_concepts.definition: A magic item that possesses sentience and personality, behaving like a character with its own ideals, bonds, and flaws.

rule_logic.premise: An item is identified as a sentient magic item
rule_logic.implication: It functions as an NPC under the GM's control
rule_logic.description_text: Sentient magic items function as NPCs under the GM's control.

extracted_concepts.definition: Rules governing the control of activated properties for sentient magic items.

rule_logic.premise: A sentient magic item has an activated property
rule_logic.implication: The activated property is under the item's control, not its wielder's
rule_logic.description_text: Any activated property of the item is under the item's control, not its wielder's.

extracted_concepts.definition: The condition and outcome when a wielder maintains a positive relationship with a sentient magic item.

rule_logic.premise: Wielder maintains a good relationship with a sentient magic item
rule_logic.implication: Wielder can access the item's activated properties normally
rule_logic.description_text: As long as the wielder maintains a good relationship with the item, the wielder can access those properties normally.
related_search_terms: how to use sentient item powers

extracted_concepts.definition: The consequences that occur when the relationship between a wielder and a sentient magic item becomes strained.

rule_logic.premise: Relationship between wielder and sentient magic item is strained
rule_logic.implication: The item can suppress its activated properties OR turn them against the wielder
rule_logic.description_text: If the relationship is strained, the item can suppress its activated properties or even turn them against the wielder.

extracted_concepts.definition: A rule stating that consumable magic items cannot be sentient.

rule_logic.premise: An item is a consumable item (e.g., potion, scroll)
rule_logic.implication: Item is never sentient
rule_logic.description_text: Consumable items such as potions and scrolls are never sentient.

source_chapter: Dungeon Master's Guide - Sentient Magic Items

extracted_concepts.definition: The process of establishing a magic item's persona, including its mental abilities, communication methods, senses, alignment, and special purpose, following NPC creation guidelines with specific item-related exceptions.

rule_logic.premise: DM decides to make a magic item sentient
rule_logic.implication: Create the item's persona similar to an NPC, applying specific rules for abilities, communication, senses, alignment, and purpose.
rule_logic.description_text: When you decide to make a magic item sentient, you create the item's persona in the same way you would create an NPC, with a few exceptions described here.

extracted_concepts.definition: The Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma scores assigned to a sentient magic item, determining its cognitive and social capabilities.

rule_logic.premise: A magic item is sentient
rule_logic.implication: It possesses Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma scores. These can be chosen by the DM OR determined randomly by rolling 4d6 (dropping the lowest) for each score.
rule_logic.description_text: A sentient magic item has Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma scores. You can choose the item's abilities or determine them randomly. To determine them randomly, roll 4d6 for each one, dropping the lowest roll and totaling the rest.

extracted_concepts.definition: The method by which a sentient magic item conveys its thoughts, emotions, or speech, ranging from emotional transmission to telepathy or verbal speech in languages.

rule_logic.premise: A magic item is sentient
rule_logic.implication:
It has an ability to communicate. The DM can choose the method OR roll on a d100 table:
  - 01-60: Transmits emotion to wielder.
  - 61-90: Speaks, reads, and understands languages.
  - 91-100: Speaks, reads, understands languages AND communicates telepathically with wielder.
rule_logic.description_text: A sentient item has some ability to communicate, either by sharing its emotions, broadcasting its thoughts telepathically, or speaking aloud. You can choose how it communicates or roll on the following table.

extracted_concepts.definition: The perceptual capabilities of a sentient magic item, allowing it to be aware of its surroundings within a limited range.

rule_logic.premise: A magic item is sentient
rule_logic.implication:
It can perceive its surroundings. The DM can choose its senses OR roll on a d4 table:
  - 1: Hearing and normal vision out to 30 feet.
  - 2: Hearing and normal vision out to 60 feet.
  - 3: Hearing and normal vision out to 120 feet.
  - 4: Hearing and darkvision out to 120 feet.
rule_logic.description_text: With sentience comes awareness. A sentient item can perceive its surroundings out to a limited range. You can choose its senses or roll on the following table.

extracted_concepts.definition: The moral and ethical compass that guides a sentient magic item's behavior and personality.

rule_logic.premise: A magic item is sentient
rule_logic.implication: It possesses an alignment. The DM can choose an alignment (possibly suggested by its nature/creator) OR roll on a d100 table for a random alignment.
rule_logic.description_text: A sentient magic item has an alignment. Its creator or nature might suggest an alignment. If not, you can pick an alignment or roll on the following table.

extracted_concepts.definition: A primary objective or goal that a sentient magic item relentlessly pursues, which can dictate its cooperation or conflict with its wielder.

rule_logic.premise: A magic item is sentient and is given a special purpose
rule_logic.implication: IF wielder's actions align with purpose THEN item remains cooperative. IF wielder deviates from purpose THEN conflict may arise, potentially causing the item to prevent use of its activated properties. The DM can choose a purpose OR roll on a d10 table for a random purpose.
rule_logic.description_text: You can give a sentient item an objective it pursues, perhaps to the exclusion of all else. As long as the wielder's use of the item aligns with that special purpose, the item remains cooperative. Deviating from this course might cause conflict between the wielder and the item, and could even cause the item to prevent the use of its activated properties. You can pick a special purpose or roll on the following table.

extracted_concepts.definition: A state of disagreement that arises when a sentient magic item's wielder acts contrary to the item's alignment or purpose, potentially leading to the item imposing demands or exerting control.

rule_logic.premise: A sentient item's wielder acts in a manner opposed to the item's alignment or purpose
rule_logic.implication: Conflict arises; the sentient item makes a Charisma check contested by the wielder's Charisma check
rule_logic.description_text: A sentient item has a will of its own, shaped by its personality and alignment. If its wielder acts in a manner opposed to the item's alignment or purpose, conflict can arise. When such a conflict occurs, the item makes a Charisma check contested by the wielder's Charisma check.

extracted_concepts.definition: Demands made by a sentient item upon its wielder if the item wins a contested Charisma check during a conflict.

rule_logic.premise: A sentient item wins a Charisma check contested by its wielder
rule_logic.implication: The item makes one or more demands: insists on being carried/worn at all times, demands disposal of repugnant items, demands pursuit of its goals exclusively, OR demands to be given to someone else
rule_logic.description_text: If the item wins the contest, it makes one or more of the following demands: The item insists on being carried or worn at all times. The item demands that its wielder dispose of anything the item finds repugnant. The item demands that its wielder pursue the item's goals to the exclusion of all other goals. The item demands to be given to someone else.

extracted_concepts.definition: Actions a sentient item can take if its wielder refuses to comply with its demands after winning a conflict contest.

rule_logic.premise: A sentient item's wielder refuses to comply with the item's demands
rule_logic.implication: The item can do any or all of the following: Make it impossible for its wielder to attune to it; Suppress one or more of its activated properties; Attempt to take control of its wielder
rule_logic.description_text: If its wielder refuses to comply with the item's wishes, the item can do any or all of the following: Make it impossible for its wielder to attune to it. Suppress one or more of its activated properties. Attempt to take control of its wielder.

extracted_concepts.definition: The process by which a sentient item attempts to directly control its wielder.

rule_logic.premise: A sentient item attempts to take control of its wielder
rule_logic.implication: The wielder must make a Charisma saving throw (DC = 12 + the item's Charisma modifier)
rule_logic.description_text: If a sentient item attempts to take control of its wielder, the wielder must make a Charisma saving throw, with a DC equal to 12 + the item's Charisma modifier.

extracted_concepts.definition: The condition applied to a wielder who fails a saving throw against a sentient item's control attempt.

rule_logic.premise: A wielder fails a Charisma saving throw against a sentient item's control attempt
rule_logic.implication: The wielder is charmed by the item for 1d12 hours and must try to follow the item's commands
rule_logic.description_text: On a failed save, the wielder is charmed by the item for 1d12 hours. While charmed, the wielder must try to follow the item's commands.

extracted_concepts.definition: A specific condition allowing a charmed wielder to attempt to end the charmed effect early.

rule_logic.premise: A wielder charmed by a sentient item takes damage
rule_logic.implication: The wielder can repeat the saving throw, ending the effect on a success
rule_logic.description_text: If the wielder takes damage, it can repeat the saving throw, ending the effect on a success.

extracted_concepts.definition: A limitation on how frequently a sentient item can attempt to take control of its wielder.

rule_logic.premise: A sentient item attempts to control its wielder (regardless of success or failure)
rule_logic.implication: The item can't use this power again until the next dawn
rule_logic.description_text: Whether the attempt to control its user succeeds or fails, the item can't use this power again until the next dawn.
